text: But for instance, Kyle amendment obvs very different to a straight-up People's vote amendment, as it it contingent on deal support. Point Bercow is making with May deal is the content & purpose is literally identical.
author: IanDunt

text: By virtue of allowing Benn amendment after Cooper-Boles, or May deal twice, that clearly will not work. But everyone on all sides of the debate, heavily impacted by what's going on here.
author: IanDunt

text: Repeated efforts by Brexiters to insist that this means People's Vote is dead because that amendment was defeated last week. Bercow says it;s a context and circumstance decision.
author: IanDunt

text: "But it would seem to me to be helpful if people showed respect for each other in these circumstances... listened to what others had to say, but if they choose not to do so, so be it."

text: "I didn't include him in the category of very senior people in the House, that is a debatable proposition, I readily grant."

text: "I would hope the govt would feel respect for procedure does matter. I note that as the rt hon gentleman asks his question and I respond, the leader of the House is playing with her electronic device and so is the deputy chief whip."

text: On test for another meaningful vote: "Demonstrable change to the proposition would be required. Simply a change about an opinion about something wouldn't constitute a change in the offer."
author: IanDunt

text: "Others can proceed as they wish, but I have never been pushed around and I'm not going to start now."
author: IanDunt

text: Bercow looks with a harsh glare at the government front bench. "Part of the responsibility of the Speaker is to frankly to speak truth to power. I have always done that and no matter what I always will.
author: IanDunt

text: This is fucking hilarious.
author: IanDunt

text: Quick caveat to all this. Govt can try to pass a motion putting aside the normal rules in a specific case. They could try that here, saying it can be put down as often as they like. Trouble is: They'd need a majority for that.
author: IanDunt

text: Soubry: "This is what happens when you don't seek compromise and consensus from the beginning."
author: IanDunt

text: Bercow says "everything depends upon context and circumstance... manifestly and incontrovertibly".
author: IanDunt

text: Francois makes a decent point. Benn amendment last week was substantially similar to Cooper-Boles amendment from a month ago. He judged it was permissible, cos not exactly the same. So if it comes up again, Bercow will surely have to block it.
author: IanDunt

text: Nowhere in that list was reflecting the "will of the House", which was thought to be the dominant guiding principle in his decision on this matter.
author: IanDunt

text: 3) "Underlying all of that there is a concept of respect for the importance of decisions made by the House and weight to be attached to them."
author: IanDunt

text: He lists: 1) "Concern with judicious use of parliamentary time when that time is finite." 2) "Ensuring clarity and consistency so far as the statute book is concerned."
author: IanDunt

text: Bercow lists the rational behind his decision-making on the subject. Important to note. "
author: IanDunt

text: The shit that is going down here? It is fucking insane. Insane.
author: IanDunt

text: This is basically a constitutional nerd orgasm explosion.
author: IanDunt

text: Angela Eagle, who asked Bercow about this last week, says the section in Erskine May is to prevent "bullying" by the executive.
author: IanDunt

text: Bercow says it is "self-evidently valid".
author: IanDunt

text: Mogg up. Sarcastically says he is delighted Speaker is following precedent finally. Important moment: Says a new session after prerogation would allow another vote.
author: IanDunt

text: Interestingly, Bill Cash, ardent Brexiter, rises to congratulate Bercow on what he said.
author: IanDunt

text: For more details on this, see this piece from this morning - but health warning: It is now clear Bercow is taking a much stricter interpretation of the rules than I laid out there
author: IanDunt

text: Ie: If votes were shifting towards govt, that would suggest will of the House was for another vote. And Speaker would take note of that. But no mention of that at all from Bercow.
author: IanDunt

text: But that is a much narrower assessment, and a much higher benchmark, than that which many constitutional experts have. They thought the "underlying reality", to quote one of the clerks of the House, were relevant on the motion.
author: IanDunt

text: He did not quite rule out another vote on the motion. However, his argument was reliant on text of the deal and whether it had changed in negotiations with Europe.
author: IanDunt

text: OK, that was odd.
author: IanDunt

text: "What govt cannot properly do is resubmit to the House the same propitiation or substantially the same proposition as that which was rejected last week".
author: IanDunt

text: "If govt wishes to bring forward new proposition that is neither the same nor substantially the same as that disposed of in the House" last week, that's in order.
author: IanDunt

text: He says it is rumoured, but he hasn't been informed, that third and then fourth meaningful votes will be tabled.
author: IanDunt

text: Guys, I'm pretty sure he's about to do this shit right now and it is going to blow the fucking lid right off this thing.
author: IanDunt

text: Second motion didn't fall foul because "it could credible be argued that it was a different proposition" to that put earlier - the legal changes with EU.
author: IanDunt

text: First vote defeated more heavily than any govt motion in parliamentary history. Second vote was "again very heavily defeated".
author: IanDunt

text: "I pointed out at the time this was deeply discourteous to the House." He sought a vote on it. "Regrettably it was not."
author: IanDunt

text: Now summarises chronology with Brexit deal. Published Nov 14th. Was supposed to be voted in Dec. But it was postponed, after over a 100 speeches made in debate.
author: IanDunt

text: "It is a necessary rule to ensure the sensible use of House's time. Decisions of the House matter. They have weight."
author: IanDunt

text: Reminds House it is up to 'chair' - that's him - to decide if substance of motion is the same. He says Chris Bryant quoted examples of the ruling being reasserted last week. Each time Speaker ruled motion couldn't be brought back.
author: IanDunt

text: Holy fuck, is he about to do this? It really sounds like he might.
author: IanDunt

text: Says he's been asked to pronounce on it by both sides of House and Brexit debate. Quotes the relevant section of Erskine May
author: IanDunt

text: This is weird. He couldn't possibly do this could he?
author: IanDunt

text: Says there's been lots of speculation about meaningful vote three. On March 13th he was asked about whether it is proper to keep bringing the deal back. He said no ruling necessary at the time but may be required later.
author: IanDunt

text: At that point, there's no point whining or blaming May. Anyone who writes in support of it or votes for it now must take responsibility for what it entails.
author: IanDunt

text: But let's be clear - once you support it, it's on you. If it passes, God help us, Britain is in a legal chokehold for the foreseeable future.
author: IanDunt

text: Remainer or Leaver: how anyone could bring themselves to support anything as piss-poor as May's deal will always be a bafflement to me.
author: IanDunt

text: Imagine spending years railing against the undemocratic nature of the EU and then backing a deal that puts EU legal changes directly on the Northern Irish statute book.
author: IanDunt

text: It would be quite funny to watch these people fall apart, if we didn't all have to live with the consequences of their nonsense.

text: Which is your favourite? Turns out mine is consistent idiocy.

text: Right here you go, the answer to the question you've all been asking: Exactly how many fucking times can May bring this deal back to the Commons?
author: IanDunt

text: I don't think it will. But a good showing for it this week could potentially start to pivot pro-deal Tories towards it for another meaningful vote later on.
author: IanDunt

text: It's an attempt to bully the DUP into backing deal. Might work, might not - no-one knows. The next 36 hours are everything. Personally, I feel fairly confident May can't win it - at least this week.
author: IanDunt

text: Sub-plot to Brexit shenanigans: what actually is Davis up to? Does even he know anymore?

text: This appears to be the base-level of irreconcilables. No matter what Mogg, DUP etc do, this suggests May would need a hefty swing of Brexity Labour MPs to have any chance of passing the deal.

text: Corbyn is so evasive and misleading that after nearly three years, and weeks before the Article 50 deadline, journalists have to ask: "So your preference is to leave the EU?"

text: It's not a sci-fi sequel. It's a shameful piece of parliamentary fuckwittery.

text: Guys we don't have to call it MV3. WE CAN MAKE OUR OWN DESTINY. It is the most painful, embarrassing, toe-curling, fucking dreadful name I could imagine. Just don't use it.

text: Presume any lawyer here my age chose the profession because of that programme. I chose cigarettes for breakfast, for years, because Anna was the coolest person I'd ever seen.
